title: Why do people call African Americans black? - Quora

response.answer_text: In the 50s’ we were called colored people. Colored was often taken as a slur, even when not so intended. Negro became the accepted term through most of the 60s’. In the late 1960s’ and early 70s’, after the release of James Brown's song “Say it Loud”(I’m Black and I’m Proud”) many people were encouraged to go by the term “black”. Consequently, we became Black people. In the late 80s’ the Rev. Jessee Jackson began referring to blacks as African American, which continues up until today. The problem with this is that all blacks are not “originally from Africa.” Black American-Puerto-Ricans and Panamanians, among many others, are classified as “African-American” under today’s classification of black Americans. Some people have begun to use the term: “people of color”. It is a useful term because defining someone by a negative — nonwhite or other than white — seems silly. But some whites object to the phrase, too, because, they have no color. It is really much more complicated than it needs to be. footnote: all that I wrote came from my” east coast” memories from my lifetime. Please don’t quote me because my memories could differ from somebody else’s.

Why do people call black people African American? “African-American” is a reasonably accurate and non-pejorative label for a culture. The ancestors of today’s African Americans were drawn from many different groups and then deprived of their original cultures when they were kidnapped, transported, enslaved, and forced to live in communities with strangers from widely separated areas. They had to communicate with people speaking many languages and were treated by the European culture as a single cultural block, ignoring their diverse origins. In response, they quickly adopted a new language and developed a new culture mixing elements of their African cultures with their experience in the new environment. This culture was distinctly American since it arose in the United States, it was distinctly different from European American culture having its own dialect, art, music, dance, cuisine, belief structures, etc, and it was distinctly African including elements drawn from various African sources. It makes sense to call this culture African-American. And just as we identify some groups as Italian-American or Irish-American to recognize the contribution of those homelands to the culture of their American cousins, why would we not do the same for African-Americans?
